The court said fact that the offences, which were at the center of the discrimination, also violated the rights to privacy and dignity strengthened the conclusion that the discrimination against gay men was unfair and such inconsistent with section 9 of the Constitution. The court held that the offences were all aimed at prohibiting sexual intimacy between gay men and violated their right to equality provided for in section 9 of the Constitution in that they unfairly discriminated against gay men on the basis of sexual orientation. Such discrimination was presumed to be unfair since the Constitution expressly included sexual orientation as a prohibited ground of discrimination.
cases.decision: The court in a unanimous decision held that there was no legitimate reason as to why the rights of gay men should be limited. The court concluded that the common law offence of sodomy, its inclusion in certain statutory schedules, and the relevant section of the Sexual Offenses Act were not reasonable or justifiable limitations on the rights of gay men to equality, dignity and privacy. The offences were accordingly found to be unconstitutional and invalid.
cases.dissent: In a separate concurring judgement, Sachs J, held that the scope of what is constitutionally normal had expanded and included the widest range of perspectives to acknowledge, accommodate and accept the largest spread of difference. The decision of the court should thus be seen as part of a growing acceptance of difference in an increasingly open and pluralistic South Africa.

cases.title: Centre For Child Law and Others v Media 24 Limited and Others
cases.justicesConcurring: Mhantla J
cases.summary:
The SCA had declared section 154(3) of the Criminal Procedure Act unconstitutional and invalid to the extent that the provision did not protect the identity of child victims in criminal proceedings. The applicants requested a declaration that section 154(3) should protect the anonymity of child victims of crime when properly interpreted. In 1997, the second applicant, was taken from her biological parents whilst in the maternity ward at a hospital. In 2015 when the applicant was 17 years old, she was found by her biological parents. Her abductor was criminally charged and prosecuted, and the applicant was a potential, witness in the trial. The trial was scheduled to begin after applicant’s 18th birthday. Concerned by the media attention, the second applicant approached the first applicant, the Centre for Child Law, for legal support. The Centre for Child Law wrote to all major media houses and requested that they don’t reveal the first applicant’s identity.

The applicants requested a declaration that section 154(3) should protect the anonymity of child victims of crime when properly interpreted. The media respondents asserted that the two extensions of section 154(3) are constitutionally impermissible, as they are in conflict with the rights to freedom of expression and the principle of open justice. The issue before the court was that section 154(3) expressly provided anonymity protection for child accused or witnesses in criminal proceedings, however, the protection did not extend to child victims. The court also had to determine whether the protection afforded by section 154(3) should extend into adulthood for child accused, witnesses and victims.

The court held that the predominant purpose of section 154(3) of the Criminal Procedure Act was child protection. Protection from the potentially harmful effects of the publication of their names and identities as a result of being implicated in criminal proceedings. Since this protection is only afforded to child accused and witnesses, there was a gap in the law as it pertained to protecting child victims in criminal proceedings. The court held that the exclusion of child victims in section 154(3) limited the right to equality, as it constituted a one-sided differentiation that did not offer equal protection and benefit of the law. The court found that rights of children, their dignity and privacy were inherently linked, as each child had their own “individual dignity, special needs and interests”. To not have control over how some of the most traumatic and intimate moments of a child’s life are shared with the public attacked the very core of the child’s dignity.
cases.decision: The court found that the right to dignity limited the reach of the right to freedom of expression, which is guaranteed by section 16 of the Constitution and included the right of the media to publish information. The right to publish information was not to be used to justify the breach of the right to dignity. The court found that limitations arising from a failure to provide ongoing protection were not justified. The purpose of freedom of expression and open justice were compelling, but when it came to the balancing of these competing rights, the best interests of children, the right to dignity and privacy outweighed the barrier to the principle of open justice. The serious harms caused to child participants, overshadow the minimal harm to open justice. The granting of the default ongoing protection would not present a harsh interference into media freedom.
cases.dissent: Cameron J, Froneman J and Jafta J agreed with the majority decision on the issue of victim protection but differed on the issue relating to ongoing protection. The court held that the right to freedom of expression and the principle of open justice tipped the scales in favour of a default regime in which anonymity protection ended when a child participant reaches 18 years, unless a court expressly extends the protection. The dissenting Justices held further that the conclusion that the rights to dignity, privacy and the best interests of the child were infringed was hard to understand in the context of the ongoing protection. This was because the issue was that section 154(3) failed to protect children when they turn 18 years of age hence the fear that the media were going to publish the first applicant’s identity when she turned 18. Otherwise before that she had been adequately protected by the section.

cases.title: Union of Refugee Women and Others v Director, Private Security Industry Regulatory Authority and Others
cases.justicesConcurring: Kondile AJ
cases.summary:
The applicants made an application regarding the rights of refugees to work in the private security industry in South Africa. The Private Security Industry Regulation Act 56 of 2001 required security service providers to register with the Private Security Industry Regulatory Authority. Section 23(1)(a) of the Security Act listed citizenship or permanent residence as a requirement for registration. Despite the provisions of section 23(1)(a), section 23(6) granted the Authority the decision to register any applicant as a security service provider, on good cause shown and on grounds which are not in conflict with the purpose of the Security Act and the objects of the Authority. The applicants challenged section 23(1)(a) on the basis that it constituted a violation of the right to equality and discriminated against them on the basis that they are not citizens or permanent residents. All of the respondents opposed the application.

The Private Security Industry Regulation Act 56 of 2001 required security service providers to register with the Private Security Industry Regulatory Authority. Section 23(1)(a) of the Security Act listed citizenship or permanent residence as a requirement for registration. The applicants argued that section 23(1)(a) was unconstitutional on the basis that it constituted a violation of the right to equality and discriminated against them on the basis that they are not citizens or permanent residents. The issue before the court was whether the provision of the Security Act to the extent it excluded refugees from its scope was unconstitutional.

The court held that while refugees were fully entitled to work in South Africa, section 22 of the Constitution limited the right to choose a job to citizens only. The right to equality was held not to be violated by section 23 of the Security Act. The court held that the private security industry was a special environment and at stake was the safety and security of the public at large. Section 12 of the Constitution provides everyone the right to freedom and security of the person, which included the right to be free from all forms of violence from either public or private sources. In a society damaged by violent crime, the importance of protecting this right could not be exaggerated.
cases.decision: The court held that the regulatory scheme was carefully designed for the purpose of screening entrants to the private security industry rather than constituting a blanket ban on the registration of refugees as private security service providers. Section 12 of the Constitution provides everyone the right to freedom and security of the person, which included the right to be free from all forms of violence from either public or private sources. That is not to say that foreign nationals, including refugees, are inherently less trustworthy than South Africans. In a country where xenophobia has caused increased suffering, it is important to stress this and that it was not that the Authority did not trust refugees. The Security Act was designed to limit eligibility for registration to people whose trustworthiness could be objectively verified. The preamble to the Act acknowledges that the right to security of the person is fundamental to the well-being and to the social and economic development of every person.
cases.dissent: In their dissenting judgement, Mokgoro J and O'Regan J held that section 23(1)(a) of the Private Security Industry Regulation Act discriminated unfairly on the basis of refugee status. The court was not convinced that the purpose identified by the Minister to ensure that security service employees were trustworthy was really provided by the section. The dissenting judgment held that the order it would have proposed was to require that refugees who could meet the other requirements of the Act should not be barred from registration as security service providers. Those refugees who cannot meet those requirements should seek to establish that “good cause” exists for them to be registered as contemplated by section 23(6).

cases.title: NM and Others v Smith and Others [2007] ZACC 6; 2007 (5) SA 250 (CC); 2007 (7) BCLR 751 (CC)
cases.justicesConcurring: Madala J, Moseneke DCJ, Mokgoro J, Skweyiya J, Van der Westhuizen J, Yacoob J, Sachs J, Langa J and O’Regan J.
cases.summary:
The applicants who were HIV positive were involved in clinical trials. During these clinical trials, they raised concerns about the illnesses and fatalities amongst the patients. One of the concerns raised was that the consent forms for their trials were not explained to them. The second respondent was appointed to investigate the applicants' allegations. The second respondent then appointed a third party to conduct the investigation. The third-party issued a report that contained the names of the applicant but this report was sent to a few people. The first respondent was approached by the third respondent who wanted to write a biography about the second respondent. The published biography revealed the names and HIV status of the applicants.

The applicants who were HIV positive were involved in clinical trials. During these clinical trials, they raised concerns about the illnesses and fatalities amongst the patients. One of the concerns raised was that the consent forms for their trials were not explained to them. The second respondent was appointed to investigate the applicants' allegations. The second respondent then appointed a third party to conduct the investigation. The third-party issued a report that contained the names of the applicant but this report was sent to a few people. The first respondent was approached by the third respondent who wanted to write a biography about the second respondent. The published biography revealed the names and HIV status of the applicants.

The applicants asked the respondents to remove their names from the book, but the respondents refused to do so.

The issue was whetther the respondent had violated the applicants' right to privacy under section 14 of the Constitution when they published the HIV statuses of the applicants in the biography. The second issue was the balancing act between the right to privacy and freedom of speech.

The court when giving out its judgement mentioned that the respondents knew that the applicants had not given consent to have their HIV status published but they had gone ahead and published their names. This violated the applicants' rights to privacy and dignity.

The respondents could have used pseudonyms to protect the identity of the applicants. The applicants were found to have infringed on the applicants' rights to privacy and dignity and ordered to pay damages to the applicants.
cases.decision:
The right to privacy is one that cannot be interfered with unless there is a social need that allows a person’s right to privacy to be violated.

There was no public interest that justified the violation of the applicant’s right to privacy in this case. The respondents did not establish if consent had been given by the applicants despite them having time to do so.

The respondents could have used pseudonyms which would not have taken away fro the authenticity of the book. The need for access to medical information was not sufficient to breach the applicants' right to privacy. There needs to be a very good reason for the public to want to be informed.
cases.dissent:
Madala J (Moseneke DCJ, Mokgoro J, Skweyiya J, Van der Westhuizen J and Yacoob J concurring) decided that the respondents were aware that the applicants had not given their consent but still went ahead and published their names, violating their rights to privacy and dignity.

Sachs J concurring decided that even though the respondents believed that the applicants had placed their medical status in the public domain, the sensitive nature of the information meant that the respondents had to take more care in verifying this belief.

Langa CJ concurred with the two judgments above but disagreed that the respondents had a further duty to verify the information and ensure that the applicants had consented.

O’Regan J disagreed with the above judgments. He agreed that there was limited consent but found that imposing an additional duty on the respondents to ensure that the applicants had consented to the original publication of their names would impose on the respondents' right to freedom of expression.

cases.title: Minister of Justice and Constitutional Development and Others v Prince (Clarke and Others Intervening); National Director of Public Prosecutions and Others v Rubin; National Director of Public Prosecutions and Others v Acton
cases.justicesConcurring: Zondo ACJ, Cameron J, Froneman J, Jafta J, Kathree Setiloane AJ, Kollapen AJ, Madlanga J, Mhlantla J, Theron J, and Zondi AJ.
cases.summary:
Three different High Court cases were heard as one case because they were all dealing with the same matter. The three cases argued that certain sections of the Drugs and Drug Trafficking Act (Drugs Act) and the Medicines and Related Substances Control Act were unconstitutional.

The High Court declared certain sections of the above Acts to be unconstitutional and the State appealed this decision to the present court.

Three different High Court cases were heard as one case because they were all dealing with the same matter. The three cases argued that certain sections of the Drugs and Drug Trafficking Act (Drugs Act) and the Medicines and Related Substances Control Act (Medicines Act) were unconstitutional.

The issues before the court were whether:

1. Section 4(b) of the Drugs Act which prohibited the use or possession of any dangerous dependence producing substances; 2. Section 5(b) of the Drugs Act which prohibited dealing in dangerous dependence producing substances; 3. Section 22A(9)(a)(i) read with Schedule 7 of the Medicines Act that prohibited acquiring, using, possessing, manufacturing, or supplying cannabis; 4. Section 22A(10) of the Medicines Act which prohibited the sale or administration of cannabis except for medical purposes were unconstitutional.

The court decided that s 4(b) and 5(b) of the Drugs Act together with Part III of Schedule 2 of the Drugs Act and ss 22A(9)(a)(i) and 22A(10) of the Medicines Act together with Schedule 7 of the Medicines Act were unconstitutional because they violated section 14 of the Constitution.

The sections were found to violate the right of privacy to extent that they prohibited the use, possession, and cultivation of cannabis in a private dwelling personal consumption.

The appeal by the state was dismissed.
cases.decision: The right to privacy entitles an adult to cultivate or possess cannabis in private for their personal consumption and the above sections infringed on this right. That the above sections were an unjustifiable limitation on the right to privacy. The right to privacy was not limited to a home or dwelling because there are other places other than a person’s home or dwelling where prohibiting the use or possession of cannabis would infringe on the person’s right to privacy.

cases.title: Freedom of Religion South Africa v Minister of Justice and Constitutional Development and Others
cases.justicesConcurring: Mogoeng CJ, Basson AJ, Cameron J, Dlodlo AJ, Froneman J, Goliath AJ, Khampepe J, Mhlantla J, Petse AJ, and Theron J
cases.summary:
A father was accused of abusing his son and he was convicted of common assault despite him raising the defence of reasonable and moderate chastisement of a child. He then appealed this decision to the High Court. The High Court dismissed the father’s claim and ruled that the defence of moderate and reasonable chastisement of a child was unconstitutional based on age, equal protection of the law, dignity, freedom from all forms of violence and degradation, and bodily and psychological integrity.

The applicant then applied to the Constitutional Court to challenge the decision of the High Court because it said that the decision limited its right to religious freedom as provided by section 15 of the Constitution.

The issue before the court was whether the High Court’s ruling that the defence of reasonable chastisement was unconstitutional was correct.

The court agreed with the stance taken by the High Court and decided that children could be disciplined without having to use moderate and reasonable chastisement. There were less restrictive means available to discipline children. The court held that moderate and reasonable chastisement was indeed unconstitutional as it violated sections 10, 12(1)(c) and 28(2) of the Constitution.
cases.decision:
Unlike the constitutional protection available to children, the right to freedom of religion does not entitle a parent to moderately and reasonably chastise a child. The Constitution does not acknowledge a cultural right that entitles a parent to moderately and reasonably chastise their child.

The court held that there are less restrive means to enforce discipline in children. The limitation of the rights to practice their religion in moderate and reasonable chastisement was justifiable in light of the rights of the child that it violated.

cases.title: Christian Education South Africa v Minister of Education
cases.justicesConcurring: Sachs J
cases.summary:
The applicant brought an appeal before the Constitutional Court arguing that the South African Schools Act which prohibited corporal punishments in school violated the rights of parents and learners to freedom of religion.

The applicant further argued that the South African Schools act interfered with the right to participate in the cultural life of their choice, the right to enjoy their culture and practise their religion.

The applicant in their argument stated that parents delegated the authority to discipline their children to the teachers and that this delegation was in accordance with their beliefs. The applicant argued that corporal punishment in schools was done biblically and that prohibiting corporate punishment was unconstitutional because it violated section 15.

The question before the court was whether the South African Schools Act violated the rights of parents of children in independent schools who, in line with their religious convictions had consented to corporeal punishment.

The court did find that the South African Schools Act in particular section 10 which prohibited corporate punishment was a reasonable and justifiable limitation of the parents' rights under section 15. This was because the state had to take steps to reduce violence in public and private life. The state also had a duty to protect children.

The court added that it would be difficult to monitor the administration of corporal punishment in schools and there was a possibility that teachers might act excessively.
cases.decision:
Religious practises are based on faith and this is in contrast to public or private concerns which are evaluated according to their reasonableness.Believers cannot claim an automatic right to be exempted by their beliefs from the laws of the country. The state on the other hand cannot put believers in positions where they have to choose between their faith and obeying the rule of law.

While parents may no longer authorise teachers to corporally punish their children, parents are not deprived of bringing up their children according to their Christian beliefs. The effect of the South African Schools Act was to disempower schools from delivering corporal punishment.

cases.title: South African Broadcasting Corporation Limited v National Director of Public Prosecutions and Others
cases.justicesConcurring: Langa CJ, Kondile AJ, Madala J, Nkabinde J, O’Regan J, Van Heerden AJ,  Yacoob J, Sachs J  Moseneke DCJ and Mokgoro J
cases.summary:
The applicant was appealing a judgement made by the Supreme Court of Appeal where it was only granted permission to broadcast visuals of the respondents pending trial but without sound. The reasoning behind this decision was that the respondents' right to a fair trial was sufficient enough to justify the limitation of the applicant’s right to freedom of expression.

The issue before the Constitutional Court was whether the test applied by the Supreme Court of Appeal where broadcasting would not be permitted unless the Court was satisfied that justice for the respondents would not be affected limited section 16.

The court agreed with the Supreme Court of Appeal and found that allowing the applicant to only broadcast visuals without sound was a limitation of the applicant’s right to freedom of expression. However, it was justifiable taking into context the importance of the respondents' right to a fair trial.
cases.decision:
The refusal to allow the applicant to have sound recordings of the respondents' hearing affected the applicants' right to freedom of expression under section 16 of the Constitution. The public also has a fundamental constitutional right to freedom of expression and this encompasses the right to receive information and ideas.

The public should as far as possible be informed of what goes on in the courts. The right to freedom of expression encompasses the right of the media to not only gather footage and deliver it to the public but to also broadcast that footage.

However, in this particular case, the respondents' right to a fair trial as well as the impact of the broadcasting on witnesses was sufficient to justify the limitation of the right to freedom of expression.
cases.dissent:
The majority judgement written by Langa CJ (Kondile Aj, Madala J, Nkabinde J, O’Regan J, Van Heerden AJ, and Yacoob J concurring) agreed with the approach taken by the Supreme Court of Appeal that the applicant only be granted visual rights without sound.

Sachs J concurred with the majority but for different reasons.

Moseneke DCJ (Mokgoro J concurring) dissented from the majority judgement. The test used by the Supreme Court in deciding not to allow the applicant to broadcast the sound of the proceedings put the right to a fair trial above that of freedom of speech. This was an inappropriate test because there must be no hierarchy of rights and this prejudiced the right to freedom of expression. Secondly, Moseneke DCJ found that by banning sound in the visuals to be aired by the applicant, the court had failed to consider if there were less restrictive means to protect the respondent’s right to a fair trial.

cases.title: Print Media South Africa and Another v Minister of Home Affairs and Another
cases.justicesConcurring: Skweyiya J (Mogoeng CJ, Cameron J, Jafta J, Khampepe J, Nkabinde J, Maya AJ and Zondo AJ concurring)
cases.summary:
The High Court declared certain provisions in the Films and Publications Act (Act) unconstitutional.

After the Act was amended, it required publishers except for newspapers to submit for prior approval to an administrative body, publications that showed amongst other things sexual conduct that violated or disrespected the right to human dignity, was degrading or was an incitement to cause harm.

Failure to submit this material to the administrative body before publication was a criminal offence.

The question before the court was whether the provisions were in line with the Constitution and if they limited section 16, whether it was a justifiable limitation.

The court found that the fact that there had to be administrative classification before publication limited a publisher's right to freedom of expression. This limitation was not justifiable because it did not achieve its intended purpose. The court also found that there were less restrictive means to achieve the purpose.

The provision was found to be unconstitutional.
cases.decision:
The Act regulates freedom of expression in varying degrees. Freedom of speech unlike other rights does not require regulation to give it effect, relegating the right amounts to limiting it. The prior classification requirement set out by the Act limited the right.

Administrative prior classification before publication was a transfer of control from the publisher wanting to exercise the right to freedom of speech to the administrative body.

The administrative body was now the decision-maker in respect of the right to freedom of speech of the publisher because the administrative body got to determine if expression should be made public and not the publisher. The provisions were declared unconstitutional.
cases.dissent:
In the majority judgement written by Skweyiya J ( Mogoeng CJ, Cameron J, Jafta J, Khampepe J, Nkabinde J, Maya AJ, and Zondo AJ concurring), the court found that the requirement that publishers submit their work before publication was a limitation of the right to freedom of expression.

Van der Westhuizen J (Yacoob ADCJ and Froneman J concurring) agreed with the above judgement except for adding that the provision was constitutionally invalid because it embodied a system of prior restraint that was based on vague criteria.

cases.title: Chirwa v Transnet Limited and Others
cases.justicesConcurring: Skweyiya J , Moseneke DCJ, Madala J, Navsa AJ, Nkabinde J, Sachs J, Van  Der Westhuizen J, Ngcobo J, Langa CJ, Mokgoro J and O’Regan J
cases.summary:
The applicant, a public sector employee was dismissed from a state-owned company. After her dismissal, she referred the matter to the CCMA as an unfair dismissal. The CCMA failed to resolve the matter within the stipulated time of 30 days and recommended arbitration in terms of the Labour Relations Act.

The applicant did not follow this recommendation and instead approached the High Court to set aside the disciplinary hearing that resulted in her dismissal and reinstate her. The applicant argued that the reason for her approaching the High Court for relief was because she had two causes of action available to her. One flowing from the Labour Relations Act (LRA) and the other flowing from the Bill of Rights read together with the Promotion of Administrative Justice Act (PAJA).

The question posed before the court was whether the High Court and the Labour Court both had jurisdiction regarding employment disputes.

Section 23 of the LRA provides that everyone has the right to fair labour practices. This was the section that the court relied on when issuing its judgement.

Firstly the court found that the applicant was not afforded a choice of which court to bring her action. She was not be put in a preferential position because she was a public sector employee and could rely on PAJA.

Secondly, the LRA gave remedies that the applicant should have relied on. The applicant should have relied on those remedies first and if she was not satisfied, then she could have approached the High Court. The applicant's matter was dismissed.
cases.decision:
Section 23 which the LRA was enacted to give effect to serves as the main guarantee for all employees.

All employees including public service employees, except those excluded by the Act, are covered by unfair dismissal provisions and dispute resolution mechanisms.

The LRA does not differentiate between the state as an employer and any other employer. If the applicant wanted to rely on a constitutional issue, she must have first gone through the remedies provided for by the LRA before raising the issue in a different forum.
cases.dissent:
Skweyiya J ( Moseneke DCJ, Madala J, Navsa AJ, Nkabinde J, Sachs J and Van Der Westhuizen J concurring) found that the High Court did not have concurrent jurisdiction with the Labour Court because an applicant cannot have access to multiple forums to have their issue resolved.

Ngcobo J concurred with Skweyiya J and added that since the applicant had relied on a breach of the LRA, the Labour Court had exclusive jurisdiction to hear the matter.

Langa CJ (O’Regan J and Mokgoro J concurring) agreed with the outcome but disagreed with the above judges' reasoning. He did not agree that the High Court did not have jurisdiction to hear the matter.

cases.title: National Union of Metal Workers of South Africa v Intervalve (Pty) Ltd and Others
cases.justicesConcurring: Cameron J, Mogoeng CJ, Moseneke DCJ, Khampepe J, Leeuw AJ, Zondo J,  Nkabinde J, Froneman J, Jafta J, Madlanga J and Van Der Westhuizen J
cases.summary:
The applicant represented employees of the respondents who were dismissed after participating in a strike. The applicant sought to add new employers in its application in the Labour Court. The Labour Court allowed the addition but this addition was overturned in the Labour Appeal Court. The Labour Appeal Court found that the applicant had failed to refer the matter for conciliation first and as such the Labour Court had no jurisdiction to hear the matter.

The applicant represented employees of the respondents who were dismissed after participating in a strike. The applicant sought to add new employers in its application in the Labour Court. The Labour Court allowed the addition but this addition was overturned in the Labour Appeal Court. The Labour Appeal Court found that the applicant had failed to refer the matter for conciliation first and as such the Labour Court had no jurisdiction to hear the matter.Section 191 of the LRA provides that a dispute be referred for conciliation. The applicant had failed to refer the dispute for conciliation and also to join every party who was a respondent.

The main question that the applicant brought was whether s 191 of the LRA could be interpreted given the object of section 23 of the Constitution which prevented unfair labour practices.

The court dismissed the applicants' case because the applicant was aware of the law and procedures that it needed to follow and could not rely on section 23 for its failure to do the right thing.
cases.decision:
Section 23 of the Constitution allows for the existence of trade unios and also prevents unfair labour practices.

However, trade unions who aware of the procedures that need to be followed in lodging a complaint and fail to do so cannot use section 23.

The Labour Relations Act was enacted to give effect to section 23 and therefore section 23 cannot be used directly unless the Labour Relations Act is being challenged regarding its constitutionality.
cases.dissent:
The majority judgement by Cameron J (Mogoeng CJ, Moseneke DCJ, Khampepe J, Leeuw AJ and Zondo J concurring) agreed with the Labour Appeal Court.

Nkabinde J ( Froneman J, Jafta J, Madlanga J and Van Der Westhuizen J concurring) found that there had been some compliance with the Labour Relations Act (LRA) when interpreted to give effect to fair labour practices and access to the courts. Strict compliance in some instances interferes with the purpose of the LRA.

topics.title: Section 1: Republic of South Africa
topics.content:
Section one of the Constitution provides the founding values on which the Republic of South Africa is founded on. It essentially re-affirms a new state order and confirms a clear break-away from the apartheid State system characterised by unrestrained State power. It firstly confirms that the Republic of South Africa is “one, sovereign, democratic state”. This confirmation in itself is critical as South Africa was prior to 1994 divided into various homelands (Bantustans) of which Black South Africans were made citizens of. Section one furthermore confirms that the Republic of South Africa is founded on various founding values such as human dignity, non-racialism, supremacy of the Constitution and a multi-party system of democratic governance.

It is critical to note that an amendment to section one of the Constitution requires a high threshold. At least 75 per cent of the members of the National Assembly have to support the proposed amendment with a supporting vote of at least six provinces in the National Council of Provinces. It is therefore always important to question whether any proposed amendment to the Constitution indirectly affects the founding values in section one of the Constitution.
topics.snippet: Section one of the Constitution provides the founding values on which the Republic of South Africa is founded on.

topics.title: Section 2
topics.content:
Section 2 of the Constitution provides that the Constitution is the “supreme law of the Republic; law or conduct inconsistent with it is invalid, and the obligations imposed by it must be fulfilled”. This section forms part of the founding provisions of South Africa’s new constitutional order and reaffirms a clear break away from the doctrine of Parliament sovereignty.

Under the doctrine of parliament sovereignty, Parliament had the power to make any law it wished and a Court could only declare the law invalid if there were procedural defects in the passing thereof. Under the apartheid state, acting under the doctrine of Parliament sovereignty, South Africa’s Parliament was not represented by all races. Legislation passed by Parliament therefore only advanced the interests of the white minority and trampled on the human rights of all other races. However, due to the doctrine of Parliament sovereignty the Courts were unable to declare an Act of Parliament invalid on the basis that it violated human rights and could only declare an Act invalid if there were procedural defects.

Under the doctrine of constitutional supremacy, all laws have to comply with the Constitution and the entrenched Bill of Rights in the Constitution. The Courts are now in the position to declare legislation that unduly infringes on a right in the Bill of Rights invalid.
topics.snippet: Section 2 of the Constitution provides that the Constitution is the “supreme law of the Republic; law or conduct inconsistent with it is invalid, and the obligations imposed by it must be fulfilled”.

topics.title: Section 3
topics.content:
Section 3 of the Constitution stipulates that there is a common South African citizenship and that all citizens of South Africa are not only equally entitled to the rights, privileges and benefits of citizenship but are also equally subject to the duties and responsibilities of citizenship. The State is obliged to enact national legislation to define citizenship and the South African Citizenship Act 88 of 1995 provides for the acquisition, loss and resumption of South African citizenship.

The recognition of the right to citizenship as a founding provision in the Constitution must be understood in its historical context. Under the apartheid State, black South Africans were not recognised as citizens of South Africa and were made citizens of defined territories (known as Homelands) under the Bantu Homelands Citizenship Act 26 of 1970. Under South Africa’s new constitutional dispensation, the right to citizenship in the Constitution is deeply couched on the recognition of equality. The right to citizenship allows a person to access various rights such as the right to political representation and freedom of movement. However it is important to understand that the Constitutional Court has confirmed at various occasions that arbitrary distinctions between citizens and non-citizens are not consistent with the Constitution and the rights in the Bill of Rights are afforded to everyone, with certain exceptions.
topics.snippet: Section 3 of the Constitution stipulates that there is a common South African citizenship and that all citizens of South Africa are not only equally entitled to the rights, privileges and benefits of citizenship but are also equally subject to the duties and responsibilities of citizenship.

topics.title: Section 4
topics.content:
Section 4 of the Constitution provides that the national anthem of the Republic of South Africa is determined by proclamation. Up until 1994, South Africa’s official national anthem was Die Stem van Suid-Afrika, which was based on a 1918 poem by CJ Langenhoven. In 1994, former President Nelson Mandela announced that in addition to Die Stem van Suid-Afrika, Nkosi Sikelel’ IAfrika would also be a national anthem. Nkosi Sikelel’ IAfrika was originally a church hymn but was later associated with the African National Congress and was regularly sung in defiance of the apartheid regime. In 1997, Former President Nelson Mandela proclaimed the new national anthem for the Republic of South Africa, which is a combined version of “Nkosi Sikelel iAfrika” and “Die Stem van Suid-Afrika” (“The Call of South Africa”).

The national anthem reflects a commitment to heal the divisions of the past as per the Preamble of the Constitution and reflects unity in diversity.
topics.snippet: Section 4 of the Constitution provides that the national anthem of the Republic of South Africa is determined by proclamation.

topics.title: Section 5
topics.content: Section 5 of the Constitution provides that the national flag of the Republic is black, gold, green, white, red and blue, as described and sketched in Schedule 1 to the Constitution. The national flag was designed by a former South African State Herald, Mr Fred Brownwell. The national flag was used for the first time on 27 April 1994 and the central design of the flag, the ‘V’ form flowing into a single horizontal band according to official the Government publications may be interpreted “as the convergence of diverse elements within South African society, taking the road ahead in unity”.
topics.snippet: Section 5 of the Constitution provides that the national flag of the Republic is black, gold, green, white, red and blue, as described and sketched in Schedule 1 to the Constitution.

topics.title: Section 6
topics.content:
Section 6 of the Constitution recognises that the official languages of the Republic are Sepedi, Sesotho, Setswana, siSwati, Tshivenda, Xitsonga, Afrikaans, English, isiNdebele, isiXhosa and isiZulu. This section further recognises the “historically diminished use and status of the indigenous languages” and obliges the State to take “practical and positive measures to elevate the status and advance the use of these languages”. National and provincial governments are furthermore obliged to regulate and monitor the use of official languages by legislative and other measures and all official languages must be treated equitably.

The Use of Official Languages Act 12 of 2012 has been specifically enacted to give effect to the constitutional obligations in terms of section 6 of the Constitution.

Section 6 of the Constitution also obliges the creation of a Pan South African Language Board that has to promote and create conditions for the development and use of all official languages, the Khoi, Nama and San languages and sign language in specific. The recognition of the South African Sign Language (“SASL”) as the 12th official language has been a longstanding issue and in 2017, Parliament’s Joint Constitutional Review Committee recommended that SASL be recognised as the 12th official language which would require a constitutional amendment.
topics.snippet: Section 6 of the Constitution recognises that the official languages of the Republic are Sepedi, Sesotho, Setswana, siSwati, Tshivenda, Xitsonga, Afrikaans, English, isiNdebele, isiXhosa and isiZulu.

topics.title: Section 7
topics.content:
Section 7 of the Constitution provides that the Bill of Rights is a “cornerstone of democracy in South Africa”. Section 7 furthermore holds that the rights in the Bill of Rights “enshrines the rights of all people in our country and affirms the democratic values of human dignity, equality and freedom”.

The first recognition of the protection of human rights, the most fundamental rights inherent to every person, was found in the Interim Constitution and is a key development of the constitutional transformation South Africa followed after the dismantlement of apartheid laws. Chapter 2 of the Final Constitution (the Bill of Rights) reinforces the protection and fulfilment of human rights.

The rights in the Bill of Rights may be limited in terms of the Constitutional test provided for in section 36 of the Constitution and some rights have internal qualifiers as well, such as the right to housing for instance. It is however important that any limitation of a right in the Bill of Rights be tested against the Constitution in order to be justified as a reasonable limitation.
topics.snippet: Section 7 of the Constitution provides that the Bill of Rights is a “cornerstone of democracy in South Africa”.

topics.title: Section 8
topics.content:
Section 8 of the Constitution stipulates that the Bill of Rights, Chapter 2 of the Constitution, applies to all law and binds the legislature, the executive, the judiciary and all organs of state. Importantly the Bill of Rights not only applies to the State but also to natural or juristic persons, to the extent applicable considering the nature of the rights and the nature of the duty imposed. For instance, the State has to ensure that every citizen has the right to vote in the elections and this is a constitutional duty only the State can fulfil. The State may not deprive a citizen of this right. This form of application of the Bill of Rights is known as the vertical application of rights and this relationship relates more to protecting an individual against State power.

However, a constitutional right such as privacy can for instance be enforced between individuals and between individuals there is the duty to uphold this right equally. This form of application of the Bill of Rights is known as the horizontal application of the Bill of Rights.
topics.snippet: Section 8 of the Constitution stipulates that the Bill of Rights, Chapter 2 of the Constitution, applies to all law and binds the legislature, the executive, the judiciary and all organs of state.

topics.title: Section 9
topics.content:
Section 9 of the Constitution protects the right to equality and it provides that everyone is entitled to equal protection and benefit of the law. Furthermore section 9 prohibits unfair discrimination based on certain listed characteristics such as race, sexual orientation and belief and the State is obliged to design measures to protect and advance certain categories of persons that have been previously disadvantaged.

It is important to note that the constitutional guarantee to the right to equality includes both formal and substantive equality. Essentially formal equality requires that individuals in the same circumstances must be treated alike. However identical treatment alone is not enough to achieve the goal of an equal society the Constitution envisions. It fails to take into account that social, economic and historical injustices impact individuals differently and measures attempting to advance equality should address these realities.
topics.snippet: Section 9 of the Constitution protects the right to equality and it provides that everyone is entitled to equal protection and benefit of the law.

topics.title: Section 24: Environment
topics.content: Section 24 of the Constitution confirms that everyone has a right to an environment that is not “harmful to their health or well-being” and places a positive obligation on the State to protect the environment for the benefit of future and present generations. The State is obliged to publish legislation and take other administrative steps to ensure it fulfils this duty and if the State fails an individual can evoke section 24 of the Constitution. It is imperative to note that this constitutional obligation not only applies to the State but action by companies and individuals can also be measured against this constitutional obligation. An important addition in the Final Constitution was ensuring the State secures ecological sustainable developments and the use of natural resources.

topics.title: Section 25: Property Rights
topics.content:
Section 25 of the Constitution, the property provision in the Bill of Rights has both protecting and reformative provisions and it is important to understand this balance. On the on hand the right protects existing property rights and on the other hand the right aims to correct historical injustices. Section 25(1) to (3) of the Constitution essentially provides protection against arbitrary deprivation of property and stipulates the requirements for expropriation. The protection of property against unconstitutional interreference is also directly reflected in international conventions, which South Africa has to adhere to such as the Universal Declaration of Human Rights. Section 25(4) to (9) of the Constitution can be described as the “reformative provisions” and obliges the State to take action to promote land and other reforms to ensure equitable access to South Africa’s natural resources. 
In December 2019, the Ad Hoc Committee on the Amendment of Section 25 of the Constitution published the Constitution Eighteenth Amendment Bill, which aimed to amend section 25 of the Constitution to provide that where land and any other improvements are expropriated for the purpose of land reform, the amount of compensation may be nil. It is important to note that as the Bill relates to an amendment of a right in the Bill of Rights such an amendment can only pass with a supporting vote of at least two thirds of the members in the National Assembly and a supporting vote of at least six provinces in the National Council of Provinces.

topics.title: Section 28: Children
topics.content:
Section 28 of the Constitution provides a range of rights to children, extending from the right to legal identity, such as the constitutional protection of a child’s right to a name and nationality to the right to parental care and the right to be protected from exploitative labour practices.
The constitutional rights extended to children specifically in terms of section 28 of the Constitution is in addition to any other constitutional rights in terms of the Bill of Rights where applicable. The purpose of section 28 of the Constitution is to specifically protect children in vulnerable situations. The State has a constitutional obligation to enact legislation providing more detail on the rights in terms of section 28 of the Constitution and the Children’s Act 38 of 2005 has been specifically enacted to give effect to these rights.
The “best interests of a Child” standard has been cemented in the Constitution and section 28(2) of the Constitution emphasises that- “A child’s best interests are of paramount importance in every matter concerning the child”. This standard provides that in a legal dispute concerning children for instance, the Court must focus on what would be best for the child in the circumstances before focusing on the rights and preferences of the parents.  The “best interests” standard also obliges the State to take action to ensure the necessary legal and administrative structures are in place to protect children.

topics.title: Section 29: Education
topics.content:
Section 29 of the Constitution provides for education rights and it stipulates that everyone has the right to basic education and to “further education, which the state, through reasonable measures, must make progressively available and accessible.” Unlike other socio-economic rights in the Bill of Rights, the right to basic education is an absolute right and lack of resources cannot justify its constraint. With the right to further education, the State is not obliged to provide access to everyone immediately. The State is only obliged to take reasonable measures over time to provide access to such institutions.

As the right to basic education extends to “everyone” it is not only restricted to citizens and applies to non-citizens as well. Furthermore, the content of the right to basic education is not only restricted to access to available places at schools but includes teaching materials and ensuring the facilities are appropriate for learning.

Section 29(2) also provides that where it is reasonably practicable the State is obliged to provide education in an official language of choice. This right is again restricted by internal qualifiers and has been the subject of many legal disputes. Lastly section 29(3) of the Constitution provides protection for the right to establish independent schools subject to the schools not discriminating on the basis of race, registering with the State and maintaining appropriate standards. Importantly the State is not obliged to make available resources to such schools as they operate at their own expense and the State only has a negative duty not to interfere with such schools.

topics.title: Section 30: Language and Culture
topics.content:
Section 30 of the Constitution affords protection to the right to use one’s own language and to participate in the cultural life of one’s choice. It is however on the condition that these rights may not be exercised in a manner that is inconsistent with other fundamental human rights guaranteed in the Bill of Rights. For instance, the right to exercise a cultural practice must be consistent with an individual’s right to dignity and freedom and security of the person. If the right is practised in a manner that endangers a person’s life then it is inconsistent with the constitutional protection afforded in terms of section 30 of the Constitution and the State will have to intervene to protect the individual.

Section 30 of the Constitution is one of various provisions in the Constitution affording protection to ethnic, religious and linguistic groups in South Africa and also reflects international law commitments to provide protection to such groups.

topics.title: Section 31
topics.content:
Section 31 of the Constitution affords protection to cultural, religious or linguistic communities. Persons belonging to such groups may not be denied the right to enjoy their culture, practise their religion and use their language. The State may also not interfere with the rights of persons belonging to such groups to form and maintain cultural, religious and linguistic associations. It is important to note that these rights may not be exercised in a manner inconsistent with any provisions of the Bill of Rights. For instance, if a religious practice by a community harms an individual’s life then section 31 of the Constitution cannot be relied on as the individual’s right to freedom and security of the person is endangered.

It is also important to note that section 31 of the Constitution protects both the religious, cultural and linguistic interests of an individual and that of a community but for an individual to claim the rights in terms this section, the individual needs to prove that there is a link between themselves and the specific group. Section 31 of the Constitution is also specifically based on article 27 of the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights and therefore the constitutional protection afforded to cultural, religious and linguistic communities is aligned with international law.

topics.title: Section 32: Access to Information
topics.content:
Section 32 of the Constitution guarantees everyone the right to access to “any information held by the State” as well as “any information held by another person and that is required for the exercise or protection of any rights.”. The State is obliged to enact national legislation to give effect to these constitutional rights and the Promotion of Access to Information Act 2 of 2000 specifically gives effect to these rights.

The guarantee of this constitutional right is a commitment to break away from the authoritarian state enforced by the apartheid government. Access to information is critical to ensure accountability, transparency and is a powerful defence against corruption.

topics.title: Section 33: Just Administrative Action
topics.content:
Section 33 of the Constitution guarantees everyone the right to “administrative action that is lawful, reasonable and procedurally fair” and provides individuals with the right to claim relief where their rights have been adversely affected by administrative action. Administrative action involves the exercise of public power by all organs of State. The State is obliged to enact national legislation to give effect to

section 33 of the Constitution and the Promotion of Administrative Justice Act 3 of 200 specifically gives effect to these rights. Certain public action however does not fall under “administrative action” and is not reviewable in terms of the Promotion of Administrative Justice Act. This for instance includes judicial action by the judiciary, the President when exercising his powers in terms of the Constitution, the legislature when exercising their functions and political decisions by the cabinet.

The protection of the constitutional right to just administrative action reflects a deep commitment to restrain discretionary power afforded to the executive. The apartheid State was characterised by unlimited power afforded to the State in terms of national legislation. Under South Africa’s new constitutional order such power will now have to comply with the Constitution and has to be lawful, reasonable and procedurally fair.

topics.title: Section 34
topics.content:
Section 34 of the Constitution guarantees everyone the right to have a dispute that can be resolved by the application of law decided in a fair public hearing before a court or where appropriate by another independent and impartial tribunal or forum.

This constitutional right provides a strong defence against the abuse of public power and upholds one of the founding values of the Constitution, namely the Rule of Law which essentially embraces equal protection of the law and ensures the powers of the judiciary are not usurped by the Legislature or the Executive.

It is important to emphasise that this constitutional right cannot be interpreted to mean that an individual can approach any court or independent tribunal to resolve a specific dispute as the rules of jurisdiction still apply. However, an individual has the right to approach a competent court or tribunal where appropriate to resolve the dispute and cannot be forced to waive this right.

topics.title: Section 35
topics.content:
The criminal justice system has been extensively revolutionised under South Africa’s new constitutional order and reflects stringent checks and balances to ensure police power is not abused. Section 35 of the Constitution specifically provides for the rights of arrested, detained and accused persons and the range of constitutional rights in this section will only be of application once a person falls into one of these categories.

Section 35(1)(a) of the Constitution for instance specifically provides that a person arrested for allegedly committing an offence has the right to remain silent including various other rights such as the right not to be compelled to make any confessions or admissions. A detained person in terms of section 35(2) of the Constitution, including every sentenced person has for instance the right to be informed promptly of the reason for being detained and an accused person in terms of section 35(3) of the Constitution has the right to a fair trial which includes various rights such as the right to be informed of the charge with sufficient detail to answer.

Section 35(5) of the Constitution specifically provides a remedy for breach of constitutional rights and stipulates that evidence obtained in a manner that violates any right in the Bill of Rights must be excluded if the “admission of that evidence would render the trial unfair or otherwise be detrimental to the administration of justice”.
